key: I could see a tall figure in the dark. But I can’t say who it was.
I could see some people here and there along the road. Otherwise, the place looked deserted. (= in various places — scattered about in a random and disordered way).
I couldn’t attend the meeting on account of another commitment. (= because of…).
I couldn’t find my wallet, and I didn’t remember where I had left it, but I went on the off chance of finding it in the office.
I couldn’t find the right house, and I was completely lost.
I couldn’t, for the life of me, understand the instructions. (= couldn’t understand it at all — no matter how hard I tried).
I couldn’t get him on the phone — I think he isn’t at work today.
I couldn’t get that man/what he said out of my head. (= stop thinking about him/it).
I couldn’t go early because of a problem at the office.
I couldn’t go to the party — I had some urgent business to attend to.
I couldn’t go to the wedding/ party/meeting — it was at an awkward time, you know. (= an inconvenient time).
I couldn’t hear what they were saying above the noise of the wind.
I couldn’t lend him any money — I was a bit short (of it) myself.
I couldn’t make up my mind which one to pick up. (= decide; make a decision; come to a decision).
I didn’t act as though I wanted to put away the toy, but handed it back to the child, and my action did much to reassure him.
I didn’t agree to the plan, because it flew in the face of my principles.
I didn’t buy it because there were no shops at hand.
I didn’t chat with him or anything. I just handed over the packet — that’s all.
I didn’t drop the vase at all. It just fell/came to bits in my hand. (= came apart into pieces).
I didn’t enjoy the party. Of course, the food was good. But there was nothing else to write home about.
I didn’t feel myself today, so I decided not to go to work (= felt slightly ill).
I didn’t get up in time and I missed the train.
I didn’t give it any importance at the time, but come to think of it, he looked a bit upset last week.
I didn’t have a true idea of that place until I went there.
I didn’t have any idea how to go about building a horse. So I consulted people who knew better. (= have more information and experience than me).
I didn’t have long to wait. They came out within a few minutes.
I didn’t have much teaching experience. But I taught them as best I could (= as well as I could).
I didn’t know what it was. For all I knew, it could have been a bomb (= Considering how little I knew about it, it could have been anything — even a bomb).
I didn’t know you were busy — or I wouldn’t have distrusted you like this.
I didn’t laugh, because I didn’t see the point of his joke. (= understand the essential meaning or the central idea).
I didn’t like the film. First off, it was full off violence. Then, the acting was awful. And there was not much of a story to it.
I didn’t like what had been going on there, and I decided to get word to the boss.
I didn’t like what he said, but I let it go at that. (= I ignored it).
I didn’t tell him all those things at that time, because I didn’t want to raise his hopes unduly.
I didn’t tell you all these things at the time, because no one would have taken my word for anything then.
I didn’t think too much about his remarks at the time. But I now realize I should have paid more attention to them.
I didn’t try to be pleasant to anyone or mince my words. I spoke my mind freely — without holding back anything.
I didn’t use to like classical music during my college days, but now it has begun to grow on me. (= generally become more interesting/likeable to me).
I didn’t want her to know I was hiding behind the door, but my son kept looking towards the door and gave the game away.
I didn’t want her to know that I was upset. So I put on a good face and chatted with her.
I didn’t want to discuss these things with him. It was you who set up the meeting in the first place.
I didn’t want to drag him into court. That’s why I....
I didn’t want to give him a reply just then. So I told him I’d call him back.
I didn’t want to take him to court. But he forced my hand — he didn’t repay the loan, even though I approached him several times.
I didn’t want to take the matter further, and so I didn’t make a written complaint. (= take it to a more advanced stage).
I didn’t want to take you to court and blacken your name.
I discussed the whole thing with the boss, and I tried to drive home the point that the proposal was not practicable. (= make him understand/accept this point).
I do my job to the best of my ability, but my boss is never satisfied (= as well as I can; using all my ability).
I don’t accept that careless driving was to blame for the accident. (= agree that…).
I don’t believe what you’ve just said for a moment. (= at all).
I don’t call it laziness to sit and think about a problem for a few hours. (= consider it to be…).
I don’t go along with your views on this issue. We part company here.
I don’t have a separate bed. This is a sofa and bed all one.
I don’t have any experience of negotiation. I’m a bit new to this game, you know.
I don’t have any money on me. Or I could have given you 100 or 200 rupees here and now. (= at this place and at this moment; immediately).
I don’t have time to see the film. In any case, I don’t think it’s a good film. (= and also…).
I don’t hold out much hope of getting him to change his mind.
I don’t intend to pay this fine as a matter of principle. (= because of).
I don’t know — you’ll have to ask at that counter/desk/office.
I don’t know about him, but I’ve booked myself a hotel room/a ticket for the show.
I don’t know about him/her/them, but I don’t think this plan is going to succeed.
I don’t know about others, but I for me, won’t tell this to anyone else.
I don’t know about you, but I’m going to stay here and watch TV. (= I don’t know what you are going to do/think…).
I don’t know about you, but this noise is more than I can put up with. (= You may not agree with me, but…).
I don’t know anything about that new driver. You’d better keep an eye on him/what he does. (= watch him/ it carefully).
I don’t know enough of this topic, and so I can’t pass a comment.
I don’t know her to talk to — I only know her by sight.
I don’t know him very well. I have spoken to him once or twice — that’s all.
I don’t know how far the project has progressed. I’ve lost track of it.
I don’t know how he finds the time to read all these books.
I don’t know how he got drawn into their argument. (= became involved in…).
I don’t know how he’ll be able to give the speech. He’s as nervous as can be (= extremely/very nervous).
I don’t know how I can begin to thank you. It was big of you to help us. (= kind/generous).
I don’t know how I’ll be able to get this idea/point home to him.
I don’t know how I’ll be able to live down this disgrace (= live or behave in such a way that it’s forgotten).
I don’t know how much money we owe them. I’ll have to look at the figures. (= go through the accounts).
I don’t know how the management is going to react to these suggestions — we’ll have to wait and see.
I don’t know how things stand between them at the moment.
I don’t know how to find an answer to this problem/question/difficulty. (= find a solution).
I don’t know how we’ll be able to get around this problem/situation. (= avoid/solve…).
I don’t know how you can put up with his rudeness.
I don’t know how you manage to keep the kitchen floor free of dirt.
I don’t know how, but he got the TV working again in a few minutes.
I don’t know how, but he’s managed to overcome his fear of heights. (= deal with it).
I don’t know if he has actually resigned. I have no firm information. (= definite…).
I don’t know if he’s coming here for business or pleasure. In any case, we’re glad he’s coming.
I don’t know if he’s one of our members — I’ll have to look in the books.
I don’t know if he’s telling the truth — but we’ll let it go at that.
I don’t know if I can move it by myself, but let me have a go.
I don’t know if I can take a day off tomorrow. I’ll have to clear it with the boss. (= get his permission).
I don’t know if I’ll be able to open it, but I’ll give it a try.
I don’t know if it’s true — it’s hard to tell.
I don’t know if the petrol will last (out) till we reach there.
I don’t know if the selection committee has come to a decision.
I don’t know if there’s any truth in this rumour. Anyway, let’s keep it among ourselves.
I don’t know if they know you or not — but it doesn’t make any difference one way or another.
I don’t know if we can trust him — don’t speak too freely with him.
I don’t know if you believe me, but I’m speaking from (personal) experience.
I don’t know how newspapermen get hold of these stories. (= discover/find out/ferret out).
I don’t know what exactly he does, but I think he does something in the art line.
I don’t know what finally decided him to close down the factory.
I don’t know what he paid you — but let’s call it Rs.1000. (= consider it to be…).
I don’t know what he wants us to do. I am waiting for some sign from him. He’s still inside talking to them.
I don’t know what he’s going to do when he comes to know about all this. All we can do is to hope for the best.
I don’t know what his interests are — we only talk about work.
I don’t know what his name is for sure. He gave the name of Bipin Sharma.
I don’t know what I must do to make him see sense.
I don’t know what I’d do again in the same situation.
I don’t know what I’ve done to offend him. He sounded a bit off when he said those things to me. (= sounded a bit rude/impolite/unfriendly).
I don’t know what made her do a thing like that.
I don’t know what really happened. I can’t tell you for sure.
I don’t think the defence lawyer was serious when he made those applications (in court). He was obviously playing for time.
I don’t think the exhibition was an absolute disaster. If anything, they could have organized it better.
I don’t think the Government decision is in line with the existing rules/regulations. (= in accordance with). The trouble is, his ideas are not in line with theirs. (= similar to…).
I don’t know what she did to get into her mother-in-law’s good books (= begin to be liked by).
I don’t know what they were talking about. I could only make out a word here and there.
I don’t know what to do about this problem. But if we put our heads together, we may be able to come up with a solution. (= discuss it, share our ideas and try to solve the problem).
I don’t know what to do. It’s difficult for me to decide.
I don’t know what your experience has been. But for my part, I have always found them very co-operative.
I don’t know who put the idea into his head. He says he wants to stand for the election.
I don’t know who they are, but I’ve got a pretty good idea.
I don’t know who’s been spreading this story. Of course, we know there’s nothing to it — but it creates a wrong impression, you see.
I don’t know why he changed the decision. He must have done it for reasons of his own.
I don’t know why he wants to see you — I haven’t any idea.
I don’t know why I didn’t think of it right at the start.
I don’t know why they sacked him. Part of it was that he had always been late for work.
I don’t know why they’re letting the house go like this.
I don’t know why, but he can’t hold down a job for more than a few months.
I don’t know why, but there were no more than 50 people at the wedding. (= only).
I don’t know why, but what he said sticks in my mind. (= remains firmly in).
I don’t lay claim to a thorough knowledge of this subject, but from what I know, I don’t think he’s right.
I don’t like books/films/colours/things of that sort.
I don’t like her. She thinks she knows all the answers.
I don’t like him — he thinks he’s a cut above the rest of us. (= better than).
I don’t like him shouting at me like this all the time.
I don’t like him, but I can /I’ll say this much for him:...
I don’t like my job — it’s just a means to an end (= something that I do only because it’ll help me achieve a particular result).
I don’t like the look of this — I think we’re going to get into trouble with these people.
I don’t like the sound of him — I think he’s a cunning liar.
I don’t like the sound of that cough — you should see a doctor about it.
I don’t like the sound of the news. I think there’s going to be trouble.
I don’t like this job — you know, they make us work long hours. (= start work early and finish late).
I don’t like to go about with him — he’s bad/ dull/poor company. (= not pleasant to be with).
I don’t like to stay inside and watch television. Give me open air every time.
I don’t like you going over my head to my seniors.
I don’t mind you borrowing my book, but you must return it tomorrow.
I don’t mind you playing a joke on me, but this time you went too far.
I don’t mind you waiting in my office, but keep your hands out of things.
I don’t plan to go to his party; for one thing, I’m expecting some guests; and for another, I have taken my car for a service.
I don’t really know how much this car will fetch in the open market.
I don’t remember what page I was reading — I’ve lost my place.
I don’t suppose for a moment that we’ll able to persuade him.
I don’t suppose that dress will cost more than Rs.750, if that.
I don’t suspect his love for her. It’s true love, and he wants to get married to her.
I don’t think an opportunity like this will ever come again.
I don’t think anybody will have any cause for complaint about our service. (= a reason to complain).
I don’t think anybody worked as hard on the project as Amod.
I don’t think anybody will be able to break the system as easily as that.
I don’t think he heard what I asked him. He had a faraway look in his eyes.
I don’t think he had organized his facts before he made the speech.
I don’t think he has given the matter even a passing thought.
I don’t think he has understood the point of the story/remark/joke/your argument.
I don’t think he loves his wife. He’s always unfeeling and hard towards her. (= shows no sympathy or kindness towards her).
I don’t think he married her for ‘Love’, with a capital ‘L’.
I don’t think he really regrets having been so rude. He’s just putting on an act. Don’t take him seriously. (= It’s all a pose; he’s only pretending).
I don’t think he stands a hope of winning the election.
I don’t think he was hungry. He just sat there picking at his food.
I don’t think he was speaking the truth when he told that.
I don’t think he was telling the truth. He was putting one across you (= deceiving you by telling you something that was not true).
I don’t think he’d be good for the job. He doesn’t know how to use a computer, you see.
I don’t think he’ll be able to come. He’s always on the run.
I don’t think he’ll be able to organize the picnic. It’s beyond him.
I don’t think he’ll break his promise. Anyway, we’ll have to take a chance on it.
I don’t think he’ll consider all this. He’s a hard man, you know. (= one who’s stern, unfriendly and lacking in kindness).
I don’t think he’ll do it — he’s all mouth and no action.
I don’t think he’ll ever hold down a regular job in his life.
I don’t think he’ll have any tools with him. He’ll only have a small screwdriver at the most.
I don’t think he’s cut out to be a lawyer/a teacher/a politician.
I don’t think he’s forceful enough to make a good leader.
I don’t think he’s given much thought to his future career.
I don’t think he’s going to come back — he’s gone for good. (= forever).
I don’t think he’s got what it takes to be a great musician/cricketer.
I don’t think he’s hungry. He’s just playing with his food.
I don’t think he’s in on this plan. They worked it out when he was away. (= be involved with it; know about it).
I don’t think he’s lying — he tells a perfectly straightforward story.
I don’t think he’s quite clear in his own mind what he should do.
I don’t think he’s seen you. Don’t misunderstand him. You know, he’s got a lot of things on his mind. (= He’s worried or concerned about a lot of things and is thinking about them a lot).
I don’t think he’s sincere — he always seems to be acting (a part).
I don’t think he’s told us the full story — he’s holding something back.
I don’t think her opponent stands a chance. She’s one of the best players I’ve ever seen.
He stood no chance of winning, and so he decided to withdraw from the race.
I don’t think his plans will succeed. He’s just building castles in the air. (= making plans that have little chance of happening).
I don’t think his word is any good. Let’s not depend on it.
I don’t think his work will ever improve — I given up on him. (= stopped believing that he’ll be successful).
I don’t think I can describe myself as being a socialist/communist.
I don’t think I’ll be able to attend the committee meeting today.
I don’t think it’d be easy to put this plan/proposal into effect.
I don’t think it’ll be possible to get this report done in a week’s time.
I don’t think it’s going to do you any good to wait. He won’t come back today.
I don’t think many of our Ministers are interested in serving the community. (= the general public).
I don’t think my savings will run to a holiday abroad. (= be enough for).
I don’t think she really cares for him. It’s just cardboard love.
I don’t think she’s telling the truth. This is an unlikely story. (= not likely to be true).
I don’t think that’s how the accident happened. What he told us is not borne out by the facts. (= supported by...).
I don’t think that’s how things must have happened — his story isn’t founded on facts, you know.
I don’t think the boss will agree — he’s going to be difficult about it.
